author: marksizzle
body:
Great question! Two part answer. To be honest, usually these goals are just that. Goals. Typically set a little bit out of reach to motivate you to put in the extra work. So perhaps they believe $4.50 (just an example) is realistic, and $5.50 could only happen if he was really kicking ass. Thanks for the questions.

author: nascentmind
body:
This is true very much true in India. Most of these "product" companies are heavily filled with contractors and their numbers are almost equal to greater than the permanent employees. There are multiple contractors which are basically outsourcing companies with their employees working onsite at Intel, Cisco etc.

Many a times I see that these contractors are employed to do the death march for failing products or if the company is failing, to keep them afloat. I have seen this with Renesas mobile which had their modem come from Nokia acquisition which had completely failed in the market. They then was brought by Broadcom and everyone was laid off and was again resold to some Chinese company.

author: CharlieBrown364
body:
I would recommend that you DCA (dollar cost average) into a mix of market ETFs (SPY, VOO), blue chip stocks (FAANG, MSFT, WMT to name a few), dividend stocks (not sure, maybe JNJ, PEP, AVGO, MO, O), growth stocks (PYPL, ADBE, TTD, TSLA, SQ, NVDA), and growth ETFs (WCLD, QCLD, ARKK).

Generally, having about 20-30 stocks is “diversified enough”. 

If you want to be a little risky, you could put some of your money in Bitcoin. It’s INCREDIBLY risky, but has The potential to be huge. Just don’t put more than 10% of your money into it.

If you want to have some fun, and also be risky, you could put 5k aside for swing trading and day trading. This could be playing earnings season, news articles, penny stocks, or SPACs. You should only do this if you enjoy doing it, and beware of this risk involved.

I am not a financial advisor, so don’t take my advice without doing your own DD (due diligence). I’m just a 15 year old kid with too much free time and an interest in stocks. 

Also, I’m more interested in tech stocks, so the examples I gave above are all related to tech (other than the dividend stocks and QCLN). Keep this in mind.

Also, to the rest of you, what do you think about my strategy, and what do you think about my stock picks? Anything else you think OP should know?

author: hammondish
body:
$1000 heh?
I'd find something a little more exciting than MSFT or NET...
At your age, you can afford to take some risks and wait for a company to grow. If you started 20 years ago, advice like MSFT would be like advice to buy Ford (20 years ago). 20 years ago it would have been better to buy MSFT, and not particularly risky either.

Here's what you should do.
NCNO IPOs tomorrow.
Sit at your computer or phone or whatever, and watch for this stock to start trading.
Put all your money into it the minute it starts trading.
Now you can either hold it for a couple years while it booms, or take an exit in the next day or two when it for a quick 20-30% or more.

I own MSFT, GOOG, AMZN, PYPL, and many others that have produced 100-200% gains for me, but I bought them in 2016, not now.

Keep putting your money into your account and buy 40% boring stable stocks like MSFT, but really now is kind of a questionable time to be buying stocks like NET or SHOP... these things have a LOT of room to cool off. More important than what you buy, is developing a strategy and learning to follow stocks.

If anything, I'd wait for the next dip (which I think will hit this week), and take some positions in stocks that haven't fully broken out yet, but have pretty solid long term growth in front of them (I'm looking at you AMD, EDIT, SNCR, RAMO, CRNC, ADPT).

For long, low-risk, my next investment will be FISV.
My most recent high-risk play was OSS bought last week... 30% up from there.

author: Legitimate-Assistant
body:
I work in the industry and can say that the logic is exactly how Visa, and other similar companies will be moving forward. 

For Visa, look no further than their acquisition of Cardinal Commerce(used for the aforementioned payer authentication)  and Plaid(finance data transfer) to see that Visa is dumping literal billions into new technologies and consolidating their position. While also participating in every single possible chargeable service in payment processing and using their extensive platform to cooperate with MasterCard and other card networks to create a unified payment processing ecosystem.

For Square, their big services are their merchant aquiring + gateway services and cash app(big Bitcoin volumes exchanged here), while also offering payroll and banking services.  Their value will be dependent on Cash app utilization, their ability to poach merchants from existing providers, and their ability to build new technologies while implementing existing ones into their suite of services. 

Fiserv is another interesting mover, they are helping to allow for the acceptance of Ebt transaction online, a big deal for American grocery retail with the transition to online ordering. They also are now the acquiring bank for Aldi as of July 3 and this added over 2k locations to their customer base. 

Alibaba is popular to most because we all know the online store, but they also are a FinTech provider and have Ant financial/Alipay under their belt. And they heavily invest in new technologies. 

Even PayPal is still highly profitable with potential for further growth. Using app based tech like one touch, and the overall simplicity of their process is fantastic. But it is yet to be seen how negatively they will be impacted by the universal checkout standard the big 4 card networks are set to release.


Check out FINX for a FinTech ETF and compare it's performance by % to Spy. You will be impressed.

author: Rossoneri
body:
>  this sub has really rejected the potential of this stock for no reason

The reason is that it's got 40M in market cap.  It's a tiny company that does a tiny amount of business.  Your list of "partners" paints an overly optimistic picture when it's really more of a list of "people who buy their products and people who sell products to them".  The build some specialty computing, nothing really groundbreaking here. 

Also "Puma" is one of their brands, it's not their partner.  They might be an interesting company, but the shilling and misleading posts indicate that they are closer to being pump & dump than real quality.

-----------------------------------------------

**For comparison:**

**broadberry.com** Partners: toshiba, seagate, intel, amd, windows, nvidia

**dihuni.com** Partners: lockheed, duke, intel, johns hopkins, NASA, US Navy, FDA, UCIrvine, UCSF

**abmx.com** Partners: microsoft, redhat, western digital, intel, supermicro, vmware, ubuntu

If anybody claims a company has a "partnership" without showing the contract details.  Ignore them.

body:
Yep they installed back doors on huawei, which is actually one if the reasons they pulled out of the US in 2014.

According to the report, the NSA has planted backdoors to access computers, hard drives, routers, and other devices from companies such as Cisco, Dell, Western Digital, Seagate, Maxtor, Samsung, and Huawei.

https://www.spiegel.de/international/world/catalog-reveals-nsa-has-back-doors-for-numerous-devices-a-940994.html

author: RichardCabeza
body:
So your point is spying on your own people isnbad but nothing compared to a country using its supply chain to spy on the world right?

You do know that we spied on our allies including tapping Merkel's phone right?

Heres a quote from Spiegel on the snowden report

NSA has planted backdoors to access computers, hard drives, routers, and other devices from companies such as Cisco, Dell, Western Digital, Seagate, Maxtor, Samsung, and Huawei.

https://www.spiegel.de/international/world/catalog-reveals-nsa-has-back-doors-for-numerous-devices-a-940994.html

Do you not know about this and snowden?  Like seriously?

And idk how you can make the comment theres no longer back doors.  Its like oh weve only done it 3 or 4 times but for reals weve stopped now.

author: KnightAnthony
body: Lol, there's a funny and profitable story regarding this company. I had very little idea about this one until I began looking into streaming choices due to COVID stay-at-home orders! I'm a cable cord cutter, but family wanted entertainment. So I compared mainly Netflix with Amazon, but research led me to study Roku.....and only for the remote control ability! I had a great experience with Seagate, and this Roku was giving me a similar vibe. So I took a gamble and bought 150 shares in one of my "forget-it-about" brokerage accounts. $10K is usually my starting investment, and I got it around $72 back in March. Again....TOTAL speculation and totally forgot I owned it! And if it weren't for some chatter about it yesterday, I would never had known how much it had appreciated. Lol, my PT was only $100, but when I saw that it was $150, I sold it all! Doubled my money in just a few months on something I wasn't expecting much. Might get back into it, but ROKU is not something I "love" so will have to think about it.

body:

I enjoyed watching the Eros entertainment banner when I was younger, but the scene is alot more competitive than it used to be in India in the 80s and 90s. All the top actors have launched their own production houses and tseries basically rules the music rights. 

I'm not sure how the STX merger will pan out. STX is more of a indie based company and  Indians enjoy over the top extravagant movies. Most indie productions don't bring in the box office numbers.

author: Rossoneri
body:
>  this sub has really rejected the potential of this stock for no reason

The reason is that it's got 40M in market cap.  It's a tiny company that does a tiny amount of business.  Your list of "partners" paints an overly optimistic picture when it's really more of a list of "people who buy their products and people who sell products to them".  The build some specialty computing, nothing really groundbreaking here. 

Also "Puma" is one of their brands, it's not their partner.  They might be an interesting company, but the shilling and misleading posts indicate that they are closer to being pump & dump than real quality.

-----------------------------------------------

**For comparison:**

**broadberry.com** Partners: toshiba, seagate, intel, amd, windows, nvidia

**dihuni.com** Partners: lockheed, duke, intel, johns hopkins, NASA, US Navy, FDA, UCIrvine, UCSF

**abmx.com** Partners: microsoft, redhat, western digital, intel, supermicro, vmware, ubuntu

If anybody claims a company has a "partnership" without showing the contract details.  Ignore them.
